item.title: Cat's Cradle
item.description: After Slaughterhouse 5, Cat’s Cradle is the second Vonnegut book I’ve read. I’ve heard wonderful things about Vonnegut, and this book exemplifies a lot of those, namely uncomfortable observations and a black, dry humour. The book circles a number of themes, principally the dangers of purely objective or impersonal scientific research, and the role of religion to society and people. It hits these notes well throughout the piece, but I found the meandering, seemingly powerless, plot arch a little unstable at times - like there wasn’t anything for me to reliably hold on to.
